THE NEW "PHYSICAL LAB."
"I regard the gymnasium as one of the laboratories."—A Trustee.
When the last brick is set in its plaster,
And the new heart-inspiriting cage
Stands superb, by the skill of its master,
To herald a new golden age ;
We shall tell all the world a new story,
We shall sing at our work a new song,
To the praise of this new lab'ratory
Young Hopkins' best youth to prolong.
Then our own vivified protoplasm
Shall we recreate morning and noon ;
To abridge and fill up the late chasm
Athletic, by this our new boon.
Then upon the gridiron and the campus,
Victorious the Black and the Blue,
Shall cut up a rollicking rampus
To advertise Hopkins anew.
I3iological, chemical, physical—
Are our "labs," with their fittings galore,
They're learned and lustrous and quizzical,
Yet there's room for a single "lab"more.
It's the new one that's just been erected
As a future for Hopkins and you.
The New Man we shall make (it's expected)
in Physical "Lab" number two.
For now at your death, nineteen hundred—
When the century's gone with the wind—
New Woman" has volleyed and thundered
Her Ego, her muscle, her mind.
J. H.U., you must turn this stream backward
In an end-of-the-century plan,
By sending your hearty sons trackward
To make and to vaunt the New Man.
May our new zoological garden,
Most truly yclept the new "cage,"
Contain, with the" Colonel" as warden,
The finest of lions that rage.

May the roar of their game, so athletic,
Resound to the end of the States,
Most pleasing and peripatetic,
Till Glory sits down at our gates.
J. McC. T., '96.

MODERN FICTION.
I have been asked to give a brief summary of
the "Modern Fiction" lectures, and am glad
to do so. The object of the course was to
draw attention to the Novel as an art-form
comparatively new, and to indicate its rich development during the present century, especially in the past fifty years. The Novel, as we
call it, has evolved out of a fictional history
that is, no doubt, pre-historic, and its crystallization into its present form is a recent thing.
That form is the most popular and influential
of the modern division of literature. Its study
is appropriate today, and it is sure to receive
more and more the attention of scholars.
In the Donovan course the rise of the Novel
with Richardson and Fielding in England was
traced and a picture given of the social environment at that time, which naturally demanded an organ of self-expression like this library
form. There was an increased desire for subjective personal activity ; man realized himself in society, and, as a result, the fiction of
analysis, of analytic character study, appeared
—a tendency marking modern life increasingly, so that the analytic impulse has persisted and grown ever since, giving us the latter-day Novel of analysis, wherein man in the
contemporaneous social complex is depicted.
The origin of the Novel—standing for the
new analysis as against the older romance—
having been thus explained, the analytic development was then followed in its ramifications
in the countries which have cultivated it with
success, illustrations being drawn from the
significant writers. The modern method and
art-creed known as realism — the dominant
creed of the day—was discussed in two lectures

THE NEWS-LETTER.
NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
THE CONGRESS.
At the last session of the Senate the Censor
named the candidates for the coming speaking contest. They will show their forensic
ability in debating the old war cry of the
French Revolution that "All men are born
free and equal." Senators Stearns, Hodges
and R. D. Miller were elected as advisors to
the debating team. The Censor announced
also that Professor Adams has kindly given a
gold medal for the winners. Senator W. P.
Stewart was heartily applauded for his plea for
Flawaiian annexation. Senator Brown refuted
skillfully some of Senator Clunet's arguments,
proving to him that I rawaiians were brown,
not black, and that his conception of the Monroe doctrine was rather confused. Senator
Gordon, who closed the affirmative, thought
that his opponent's arguments were no good,
anyway," and this opinion decided their defeat.
The House of Representatives met Wednesday, January 19. The session was taken up
with the debate : "Resolved, That the United
States should annex Hawaii." The main purpose of this debate was to drill the members of
the House in expressing their views forcibly
and clearly, as a preparatory training for the
Easter debate. It also afforded the Censor an
opportunity to become familiar with the voices
and mannerisms of the speakers. The question was manifestly well thought out by the
debaters and presented in a convincing and
entertaining manner. The speakers on the
affirmative side were Congressmen Levering,
Ross, French, Fischer and Mullen ; on the
negative side, Congressmen Davidson, Murkland, Morgan, Gemmil, Grimes and Guggenheimer. The affirmative side, though supported by fewer speakers, was better presented and
the House indorsed this opinion by voting that
the affirmative side had won the debate. The
dexterous arguments of Speaker French and
Congressman Ross were greatly responsible
for this victory. Congressman Fischer, with

3

his ready, adaptable wit, showed how well serious arguments could be presented in an entertaining manner. His amusing story of two
little children and a philosopher was quite to
the point. Mr. Censor announced that the
speakers selected for the joint debate at Easter
will be required to take a special course in
public speaking.
The question for the next meeting is :
"Resolved, That all. men are free and equal."
The following men have been selected by
Mr. Censor to arrange for the debate. Philip
Sidney Morgan (chairman), John Calvin
French (secretary), Robert Harold Grimes,
Philip Austin Murkland, Ferdinand C. Fisher,
Charles S. Guggenheimer. Advisory Board—
John Hendricken King (chairman), E. H.
Ross (secretary), Charles Mallory Remsen.
THE POLYCHROME.
The appearance of several books of the
long-expected "Polychrome Bible" brings
before the world again the name and fame of
Paul Haupt, and adds fresh laurels to our University. Though the foremost scholars of the
world have contributed to this stupendous
work, its inception and successful completion
are solely due to the genius and indomitable
perseverance of Professor Haupt. He conceived that the English-speaking people needed a modern English Bible, and he proceeded
to give it to them, in spite of the greatest difficulties and opposition from all sides.
At a meeting of the Philological Association
last Friday Professor Haupt gave an interesting and amusing account of the genesis of his
-Bible, dwelling more especially upon his own
conceptions of what is modern and idiomatic
English, and the difficulty he experienced in
enforcing them in the new translations. The
authorized version of King James seems to
have become invested with a peculiar sanctity,
being cherished all the more as it grew archaic
and unintelligible. This tendency to cling to

Few lecture courses at Hopkins have been
so successful as the series on "The Modern
Novel," recently concluded by Dr. Richard
Burton.
The subject was in itself so attractive, and
Dr. Burton's treatment of it was so interesting,
that the attendance became remarkable. The
course was very popular with the ladies, whose
interest led to some rather undignified scrambling for seats. Perhaps this confirms the
statement, so often made, that women are
greater novel-readers than men.
Dr. Burton's style is vigorous and energetic,
at times almost jerky. His English is precise.
His consistent use of the subjunctive was especially noticeable.
In his criticisms he represents the healthy
state of mind that he mentioned as an attribute
of the people. His views in regard to the
future of literature are decidedly optimistic. It
was easy to listen to his lectures, but hard to
take satisfactory notes. Dr. Burton knows the
value of the half-humorous, lighter touch
which so relieves the weight and dignity of a
serious lecture. A clever phrase or a bit of
anecdote sends a ripple of laughter over the

audience and renews its interest. This is a
trait of Dr. Woodrow Wilson. It is this that
makes the classroom lectures of certain in our
own faculty so attractive. Dr. Burton's popularity with the ladies culminated in a reception
in his honor at the Woman's College at the
close of the course. In another column we
print an article by Dr. Burton, entitled "Modern Fiction." It has special reference to his
lectures here, and will be especially interesting
to all who heard them.
Long life to the Anti-Vivisection Society of
Maryland ! And may their tender hearts
never become hard, nor their trustful minds
prone to doubt the passing rumor. How
charming is their simple faith ! How spontaneous and intense their sympathy for every
form of woe! But we fear their overflowing
hearts have altogether swamped their other
faculties. The charges of wanton cruelty they
bring against the Johns Hopkins Medical
School are so utterly absurd that they boomerang themselves to death. Nevertheless,
Dr. Franklin, of the Baltimore News, has
taken the trouble, in an able editorial, to show
how grossly the Medical School has been misrepresented. If we are to believe these good
people, the "doings" over on Broadway excel
in fiendish ingenuity anything ever practiced
by frenzied savage or Spanish Inquisition.
"They will take a dog, burn its nose, lay bare
its spinal column and apply powerful electric
currents, pour hot lead into its stomach, remove portions of its body and graft portions
of other animals on, tear out its entrails and
insert others, divide the brain and dip half its
body into a kettle of boiling water, and singe
the hair from its back, after having removed
its windpipe to prevent its crying." We are
all naturally very anxious to meet that dog
and ask it how it feels after so varied an experience.
It's dollars to doughnuts that our kind
friends know as much about the methods employed in vivisection as did the dog, after the
above-mentioned operation. A few isolated
facts and a very great deal of emotion can
soon conjure up a scene too hideous for mor-

5

THE NEWS-LETTER.
tal sight. In a world where there is so much
need of the positive efforts of all good people,
it seems a pity that so much misguided energy
should be wasted on the scent of a phantom.
The organization of a State association by
the Virginia students is most certainly a step in
the right direction, on which the men from the
Old Dominion are to be congratulated. Such
associations add much to the social life of men
who come to the Hopkins as strangers and
have little time and opportunity to make acquaintances. There are a number of students
here from other Southern States, particularly
North Carolina, and it is to be hoped that they
will not be behind the Virginians. A general
Southern association would also be a good
thing.

ATHLETICS.
The General Athletic Association Board
met Friday,. January 14. Mr. R. H. Grimes
was elected manager of the lacrosse team. Mr.
Robert Garrett was appointed captain of track
athletics. This is a new position. Heretofore
Hopkins has had no track team, but simply a
relay team. Messrs. Garrett and Scholl were
chosen to represent Hopkins in the Inter-collegiate Amateur Athletic Association of America, which meets in New York sonic time in
February. Mr. George Knapp,Jr., was elected
delegate to the Inter-collegiate Athletic Association of Maryland.
The attitude that Yale has taken in regard to
the proposed inter-collegiate boat race cannot
but strike an unprejudiced observer as unreasonable. The Alumni Weekly rejoices because
Yale is not to be tempted into the pursuit of
general championships, and has not grown
sensitive to the comparative prowess of other
institutions." Such an attitude of high-andmightiness is anything but warranted by
Yale's recent record in various branches of
athletics, and should she maintain her stand

she will be in need of all the"lack of sensitiveness" to outside opinion that she can muster.
Manager Grimes has written to Swarthmore,
College of the City of New York, Crescent
Athletic Club of Brooklyn, Columbia and several other clubs for practice lacrosse games,
and expects to have a good schedule for this
spring. Should we get games from all those
written to, our team will have had good practice when the championship games in the
Stevens and Lehigh come off.
Rooters are very scarce at the hockey
games. Last year rooters were out in full force,
but now it is quite a surprise if as many as
three turn up. Nevertheless, the team seems
to be doing good work. Hopkins holds second place in the Hockey League, and has a fair
chance of coming out first.
Hopkins played off the tie with M. A. C. at
hockey, and won, after a hard struggle, by a
score of i to o.

will soon be published under the editorial supervision of Professor Brooks. The price has
been fixed at $3.50, and those who wish to subscribe are requested to send their names to Mr.
N. Murray, Johns Hopkins University.
The Societe de Linguistique of Paris has offered a prize of moo francs, to be awarded in
19o1, to the best work on Romance languages,
written after December 31, 1894. Men of all
nations can compete, provided their work is
written in French, Latin or Roumanian.
Mr. Joshua Levering, Jr., was elected manager of the Glee, Banjo and Mandolin Clubs,
and appointed as his assistant Mr. Conway S.
Hodges. The Clubs had their pictures taken
Saturday last.

Elizabethan English and Hebraisms was what
Professor Haupt found most difficult to combat. In the most commonplace passages concerning Hebrew sacrifices, there was manifested a reluctance to substituting every-day
English for words that have long since become
poetic or obsolete. Many amusing examples
of this sort were cited, while to show the absurdity of reproducing Hebrew constructions
in translation, the Professor put the first sentence of a newspaper report of the student
riots at Paris into the traditional biblical form,
connecting all the clauses with that invariable
particle 'and' with which we are so familiar.
Professor Haupt hopes that his new version
will lead to an increased and more intelligent
study of the Bible, especially amongst those
who represent the wider circle of Christianity.
While his work must prove of immense service to the scholar and student, it seems hardly
likely that the new version will soon win much
favor from the great mass of Bible readers.
The half-poetic, archaic form of the old version constitutes one of its chief charms, while
any unintelligibility only increases the gratification which the religious sense finds in the
mystic.
Cuba was the subject under discussion in
the Historical and Political Science Assoc
iation on Friday evening. In the course of the
evening interesting addresses were delivered
by Dr. Latane, a recent graduate of the University, and Mr. Bump of the editorial staff of
The Sun. Dr. Latane touched upon our early
diplomatic relations in regard to Cuba, and
was of the opinion that these early relations
furnish parallels, if not prototypes, of all
the
modern complications of the question.
A
rapid resume of the historical facts was given
,
and especial attention was attracted to the
attempted intervention by the United State
s in
1873. The changed attitude of Spain
put an
end to such proceedings. This attem
pt was
vigorously denied by the State Departme
nt at
the time, and the facts were not made
public
until a year or so ago, when all the past
correspondence in regard to Cuba was trans
mitted
by the President to the Senate. Even then
this

incident was overlooked until Dr. Latane recently unearthed it amid a mass of State
papers.
Mr. Bump gave a very interesting account of
the various filibustering expeditions, especially
the famous Laurada and Woodall expeditions. The ingenuity and adroitness with
which these attempts were planned and executed, and also the fondness for Baltimore as a
starting point, was commented upon. Mr.
Bump considered Secretary Gage's contention
that Spanish Consuls in America should take
initiative in ferreting out these expeditions was
in variance with that principle of international
law practically established by the decision of
the arbitration board in the famous Alabama
case.
The meeting of the Scientific Association on
January 20 was the occasion of an interesting
address by Dr. Clarke on his trip to Russia last
summer. Dr. Clarke, with several other Hopkins men, attended, as delegate, the Inter
national Congress of Geologists, held at St. Petersburg. After the sessions of the Congr
ess
were concluded, he went on the trip through
Caucasia given to the delegates by the Russian
Government. On his return to this city he
wrote an account of this trip for THE NEWS
LETTER.
In his address Dr. Clarke, after giving some
account of the Congress, the distinguis
hed
men in attendance, and the elaborate
preparations of the Russian Government for
their reception and entertainment, described
his trip
to Caucasia. The description was
illustrated
by a number of pictures of peasant life
and of
the magnificent scenery of the
Caucasus
Mountains, reproduced on the stere
opticon
from photographs taken by members
of the
party.

deration a plan by which the whole physi
ological

building, on the corner of Ross and

streets, to a new building to be erect
ed at the
Medical School adjoining the Johns
Hopkins
Hospital.

UNIVERSITY CHAT.
A most remarkable display of heroism, undaunted courage and desperate defiance was
lately shown to the college by the seemingly
meek and humble freshmen. Putting their
heads together after the drawing class one afternoon, they resolved upon a desperate plan
which required courage and recklessness to
execute. We all shudder to think how these
tender lambs blindly exposed themselves to
danger. Instantly their plan decided upon,
they hurried down the precipitous stairs that
lead to the drawing-room, and with superhuman strength and courage they held the hall
door, thereby barring the exit of Dr. Whiteman. Resolutely they held, not one bit
daunted, as they heard the slow, firm tread of
Dr. Whiteman descending the stairs. He has
passed the second story and is now descending
to the first floor.
"They spake not a word;
But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,
Gazed each on other, and looked deathly pale."
—Richard III.
The Doctor tried the door, but it yielded
not, and brooding suspicion awakened in his
mind a realization that some outward force was
resisting his efforts. Immediately his stern
voice reached the ears of the freshmen without.
Their courage wavered, fell, rose and then departed forever. Scattered and in confusion
they ran, nor did they stop until they were
safely harbored in the quiet repose of McCoy

A PROTEST.
In our lagt number appeared an editorial,
treating of the disadvantages of the petition
concerning the rent on gymnasium lockers.
Of course, the question has two sides, and our
writer had strong convictions with the small
minority. He was, however, undoubtedly,
mistaken in supposing that a fee for the use of
lockers would deter students from exercising
in the gymnasium—simply because attendance
to gymnasium work is compulsory for all
undergraduates. This is an old rule, which
could not be strictly enforced in former years
for lack of space in the old building.
During the past years the single teams paid
their expenses by scanty contributions from a
part of the students. Under this system the
managers found themselves continually on the
verge of bankruptcy. To remedy this evil, the
new Athletic Association was formed, which
has under its supervision the expenses of all
the teams wearing the black and blue. The
income derived from a yearly rent on the lockers will place the Athletic Association, and
with it the whole field of Hopkins athletics, on
a secure financial basis. Never again will the
managers have to go begging through the
University. The equipment of teams, the salaries of coaches and trainers, will be assured
for the whole future. The eventual surplus of
prosperous years may secure, as the students'
property, the long hoped-for athletic field. The
failure to procure this money would leave
Hopkins athletics in their old stage of stagnation. The only reliable income would be the
money derived from the membership dues for
the Athletic Association, a paltry sum, as compared with the necessary expenses.
For years past we have clamored over our
lack of college spirit, of interest in college athletics. We have looked here and there for
causes, and for remedies. The cause lies with
us, the remedy can come from us only. Surely,
this is the time to prove our loyalty by consenting, one and all, to the lasting welfare of
our athletics. Let us pay.
For some of the poorest students enthusiasm
and expense can never form a pair. We have

little doubt that the Treasurer could find
means of lightening their burden.

The Y. M. C. A. District Convention, including the Associations of Maryland, Delaware, West Virginia and the District of Columbia, will be held in this city beginning January 28. The session devoted to college associations will be held in Levering Hall Saturday
afternoon, January 29. The programme is as
follows :
2:15. Opening exercises.
2:30. "The Fall Campaign," St. John's College.
2:50. "Bible Study," Johns Hopkins University.
3:20. "Religious Meetings," Western Maryland College.
3:50. "Methods of Work in Professional
Schools," Johns Hopkins Medical
School.
Each topic will be opened by a representative of the institution named.
On Saturday evening at 7:45, in the auditorium of the West Branch, Baltimore and
Carey streets, President B. L. Whitman of Columbian University, Washington, I). C., will
deliver an address on "College Work."
The annual election of officers of the Uni
versity Association will be held February t
at 5 P. M. The list of nominations will be
posted in Levering Hall one week in advance.
The day of prayer for colleges, Thursday.
January 27, will be observed by a special meeting at 5 P. M. Rev. J. H. Young, Ph. D., will
deliver a short address.

THE NEW "PHYSICAL LAB."
"I regard the gymnasium as one of the laboratories."—A Trustee.
When the last brick is set in its plaster,
And the new heart-inspiriting cage
Stands superb, by the skill of its master,
To herald a new golden age ;
We shall tell all the world a new story,
We shall sing at our work a new song,
To the praise of this new lab'ratory
Young Hopkins' best youth to prolong.
Then our own vivified protoplasm
Shall we recreate morning and noon ;
To abridge and fill up the late chasm
Athletic, by this our new boon.
Then upon the gridiron and the campus,
Victorious the Black and the Blue,
Shall cut up a rollicking rampus
To advertise Hopkins anew.
I3iological, chemical, physical—
Are our "labs," with their fittings galore,
They're learned and lustrous and quizzical,
Yet there's room for a single "lab"more.
It's the new one that's just been erected
As a future for Hopkins and you.
The New Man we shall make (it's expected)
in Physical "Lab" number two.
For now at your death, nineteen hundred—
When the century's gone with the wind—
New Woman" has volleyed and thundered
Her Ego, her muscle, her mind.
J. H.U., you must turn this stream backward
In an end-of-the-century plan,
By sending your hearty sons trackward
To make and to vaunt the New Man.
May our new zoological garden,
Most truly yclept the new "cage,"
Contain, with the" Colonel" as warden,
The finest of lions that rage.

May the roar of their game, so athletic,
Resound to the end of the States,
Most pleasing and peripatetic,
Till Glory sits down at our gates.
J. McC. T., '96.

MODERN FICTION.
I have been asked to give a brief summary of
the "Modern Fiction" lectures, and am glad
to do so. The object of the course was to
draw attention to the Novel as an art-form
comparatively new, and to indicate its rich development during the present century, especially in the past fifty years. The Novel, as we
call it, has evolved out of a fictional history
that is, no doubt, pre-historic, and its crystallization into its present form is a recent thing.
That form is the most popular and influential
of the modern division of literature. Its study
is appropriate today, and it is sure to receive
more and more the attention of scholars.
In the Donovan course the rise of the Novel
with Richardson and Fielding in England was
traced and a picture given of the social environment at that time, which naturally demanded an organ of self-expression like this library
form. There was an increased desire for subjective personal activity ; man realized himself in society, and, as a result, the fiction of
analysis, of analytic character study, appeared
—a tendency marking modern life increasingly, so that the analytic impulse has persisted and grown ever since, giving us the latter-day Novel of analysis, wherein man in the
contemporaneous social complex is depicted.
The origin of the Novel—standing for the
new analysis as against the older romance—
having been thus explained, the analytic development was then followed in its ramifications
in the countries which have cultivated it with
success, illustrations being drawn from the
significant writers. The modern method and
art-creed known as realism — the dominant
creed of the day—was discussed in two lectures

THE NEWS-LETTER.
NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
THE CONGRESS.
At the last session of the Senate the Censor
named the candidates for the coming speaking contest. They will show their forensic
ability in debating the old war cry of the
French Revolution that "All men are born
free and equal." Senators Stearns, Hodges
and R. D. Miller were elected as advisors to
the debating team. The Censor announced
also that Professor Adams has kindly given a
gold medal for the winners. Senator W. P.
Stewart was heartily applauded for his plea for
Flawaiian annexation. Senator Brown refuted
skillfully some of Senator Clunet's arguments,
proving to him that I rawaiians were brown,
not black, and that his conception of the Monroe doctrine was rather confused. Senator
Gordon, who closed the affirmative, thought
that his opponent's arguments were no good,
anyway," and this opinion decided their defeat.
The House of Representatives met Wednesday, January 19. The session was taken up
with the debate : "Resolved, That the United
States should annex Hawaii." The main purpose of this debate was to drill the members of
the House in expressing their views forcibly
and clearly, as a preparatory training for the
Easter debate. It also afforded the Censor an
opportunity to become familiar with the voices
and mannerisms of the speakers. The question was manifestly well thought out by the
debaters and presented in a convincing and
entertaining manner. The speakers on the
affirmative side were Congressmen Levering,
Ross, French, Fischer and Mullen ; on the
negative side, Congressmen Davidson, Murkland, Morgan, Gemmil, Grimes and Guggenheimer. The affirmative side, though supported by fewer speakers, was better presented and
the House indorsed this opinion by voting that
the affirmative side had won the debate. The
dexterous arguments of Speaker French and
Congressman Ross were greatly responsible
for this victory. Congressman Fischer, with

3

his ready, adaptable wit, showed how well serious arguments could be presented in an entertaining manner. His amusing story of two
little children and a philosopher was quite to
the point. Mr. Censor announced that the
speakers selected for the joint debate at Easter
will be required to take a special course in
public speaking.
The question for the next meeting is :
"Resolved, That all. men are free and equal."
The following men have been selected by
Mr. Censor to arrange for the debate. Philip
Sidney Morgan (chairman), John Calvin
French (secretary), Robert Harold Grimes,
Philip Austin Murkland, Ferdinand C. Fisher,
Charles S. Guggenheimer. Advisory Board—
John Hendricken King (chairman), E. H.
Ross (secretary), Charles Mallory Remsen.
THE POLYCHROME.
The appearance of several books of the
long-expected "Polychrome Bible" brings
before the world again the name and fame of
Paul Haupt, and adds fresh laurels to our University. Though the foremost scholars of the
world have contributed to this stupendous
work, its inception and successful completion
are solely due to the genius and indomitable
perseverance of Professor Haupt. He conceived that the English-speaking people needed a modern English Bible, and he proceeded
to give it to them, in spite of the greatest difficulties and opposition from all sides.
At a meeting of the Philological Association
last Friday Professor Haupt gave an interesting and amusing account of the genesis of his
-Bible, dwelling more especially upon his own
conceptions of what is modern and idiomatic
English, and the difficulty he experienced in
enforcing them in the new translations. The
authorized version of King James seems to
have become invested with a peculiar sanctity,
being cherished all the more as it grew archaic
and unintelligible. This tendency to cling to

Few lecture courses at Hopkins have been
so successful as the series on "The Modern
Novel," recently concluded by Dr. Richard
Burton.
The subject was in itself so attractive, and
Dr. Burton's treatment of it was so interesting,
that the attendance became remarkable. The
course was very popular with the ladies, whose
interest led to some rather undignified scrambling for seats. Perhaps this confirms the
statement, so often made, that women are
greater novel-readers than men.
Dr. Burton's style is vigorous and energetic,
at times almost jerky. His English is precise.
His consistent use of the subjunctive was especially noticeable.
In his criticisms he represents the healthy
state of mind that he mentioned as an attribute
of the people. His views in regard to the
future of literature are decidedly optimistic. It
was easy to listen to his lectures, but hard to
take satisfactory notes. Dr. Burton knows the
value of the half-humorous, lighter touch
which so relieves the weight and dignity of a
serious lecture. A clever phrase or a bit of
anecdote sends a ripple of laughter over the

audience and renews its interest. This is a
trait of Dr. Woodrow Wilson. It is this that
makes the classroom lectures of certain in our
own faculty so attractive. Dr. Burton's popularity with the ladies culminated in a reception
in his honor at the Woman's College at the
close of the course. In another column we
print an article by Dr. Burton, entitled "Modern Fiction." It has special reference to his
lectures here, and will be especially interesting
to all who heard them.
Long life to the Anti-Vivisection Society of
Maryland ! And may their tender hearts
never become hard, nor their trustful minds
prone to doubt the passing rumor. How
charming is their simple faith ! How spontaneous and intense their sympathy for every
form of woe! But we fear their overflowing
hearts have altogether swamped their other
faculties. The charges of wanton cruelty they
bring against the Johns Hopkins Medical
School are so utterly absurd that they boomerang themselves to death. Nevertheless,
Dr. Franklin, of the Baltimore News, has
taken the trouble, in an able editorial, to show
how grossly the Medical School has been misrepresented. If we are to believe these good
people, the "doings" over on Broadway excel
in fiendish ingenuity anything ever practiced
by frenzied savage or Spanish Inquisition.
"They will take a dog, burn its nose, lay bare
its spinal column and apply powerful electric
currents, pour hot lead into its stomach, remove portions of its body and graft portions
of other animals on, tear out its entrails and
insert others, divide the brain and dip half its
body into a kettle of boiling water, and singe
the hair from its back, after having removed
its windpipe to prevent its crying." We are
all naturally very anxious to meet that dog
and ask it how it feels after so varied an experience.
It's dollars to doughnuts that our kind
friends know as much about the methods employed in vivisection as did the dog, after the
above-mentioned operation. A few isolated
facts and a very great deal of emotion can
soon conjure up a scene too hideous for mor-

tal sight. In a world where there is so much
need of the positive efforts of all good people,
it seems a pity that so much misguided energy
should be wasted on the scent of a phantom.
The organization of a State association by
the Virginia students is most certainly a step in
the right direction, on which the men from the
Old Dominion are to be congratulated. Such
associations add much to the social life of men
who come to the Hopkins as strangers and
have little time and opportunity to make acquaintances. There are a number of students
here from other Southern States, particularly
North Carolina, and it is to be hoped that they
will not be behind the Virginians. A general
Southern association would also be a good
thing.

ATHLETICS.
The General Athletic Association Board
met Friday,. January 14. Mr. R. H. Grimes
was elected manager of the lacrosse team. Mr.
Robert Garrett was appointed captain of track
athletics. This is a new position. Heretofore
Hopkins has had no track team, but simply a
relay team. Messrs. Garrett and Scholl were
chosen to represent Hopkins in the Inter-collegiate Amateur Athletic Association of America, which meets in New York sonic time in
February. Mr. George Knapp,Jr., was elected
delegate to the Inter-collegiate Athletic Association of Maryland.
The attitude that Yale has taken in regard to
the proposed inter-collegiate boat race cannot
but strike an unprejudiced observer as unreasonable. The Alumni Weekly rejoices because
Yale is not to be tempted into the pursuit of
general championships, and has not grown
sensitive to the comparative prowess of other
institutions." Such an attitude of high-andmightiness is anything but warranted by
Yale's recent record in various branches of
athletics, and should she maintain her stand

she will be in need of all the"lack of sensitiveness" to outside opinion that she can muster.
Manager Grimes has written to Swarthmore,
College of the City of New York, Crescent
Athletic Club of Brooklyn, Columbia and several other clubs for practice lacrosse games,
and expects to have a good schedule for this
spring. Should we get games from all those
written to, our team will have had good practice when the championship games in the
Stevens and Lehigh come off.
Rooters are very scarce at the hockey
games. Last year rooters were out in full force,
but now it is quite a surprise if as many as
three turn up. Nevertheless, the team seems
to be doing good work. Hopkins holds second place in the Hockey League, and has a fair
chance of coming out first.
Hopkins played off the tie with M. A. C. at
hockey, and won, after a hard struggle, by a
score of i to o.

Elizabethan English and Hebraisms was what
Professor Haupt found most difficult to combat. In the most commonplace passages concerning Hebrew sacrifices, there was manifested a reluctance to substituting every-day
English for words that have long since become
poetic or obsolete. Many amusing examples
of this sort were cited, while to show the absurdity of reproducing Hebrew constructions
in translation, the Professor put the first sentence of a newspaper report of the student
riots at Paris into the traditional biblical form,
connecting all the clauses with that invariable
particle 'and' with which we are so familiar.
Professor Haupt hopes that his new version
will lead to an increased and more intelligent
study of the Bible, especially amongst those
who represent the wider circle of Christianity.
While his work must prove of immense service to the scholar and student, it seems hardly
likely that the new version will soon win much
favor from the great mass of Bible readers.
The half-poetic, archaic form of the old version constitutes one of its chief charms, while
any unintelligibility only increases the gratification which the religious sense finds in the
mystic.
Cuba was the subject under discussion in
the Historical and Political Science Assoc
iation on Friday evening. In the course of the
evening interesting addresses were delivered
by Dr. Latane, a recent graduate of the University, and Mr. Bump of the editorial staff of
The Sun. Dr. Latane touched upon our early
diplomatic relations in regard to Cuba, and
was of the opinion that these early relations
furnish parallels, if not prototypes, of all
the
modern complications of the question.
A
rapid resume of the historical facts was given
,
and especial attention was attracted to the
attempted intervention by the United State
s in
1873. The changed attitude of Spain
put an
end to such proceedings. This attem
pt was
vigorously denied by the State Departme
nt at
the time, and the facts were not made
public
until a year or so ago, when all the past
correspondence in regard to Cuba was trans
mitted
by the President to the Senate. Even then
this

incident was overlooked until Dr. Latane recently unearthed it amid a mass of State
papers.
Mr. Bump gave a very interesting account of
the various filibustering expeditions, especially
the famous Laurada and Woodall expeditions. The ingenuity and adroitness with
which these attempts were planned and executed, and also the fondness for Baltimore as a
starting point, was commented upon. Mr.
Bump considered Secretary Gage's contention
that Spanish Consuls in America should take
initiative in ferreting out these expeditions was
in variance with that principle of international
law practically established by the decision of
the arbitration board in the famous Alabama
case.
The meeting of the Scientific Association on
January 20 was the occasion of an interesting
address by Dr. Clarke on his trip to Russia last
summer. Dr. Clarke, with several other Hopkins men, attended, as delegate, the Inter
national Congress of Geologists, held at St. Petersburg. After the sessions of the Congr
ess
were concluded, he went on the trip through
Caucasia given to the delegates by the Russian
Government. On his return to this city he
wrote an account of this trip for THE NEWS
LETTER.
In his address Dr. Clarke, after giving some
account of the Congress, the distinguis
hed
men in attendance, and the elaborate
preparations of the Russian Government for
their reception and entertainment, described
his trip
to Caucasia. The description was
illustrated
by a number of pictures of peasant life
and of
the magnificent scenery of the
Caucasus
Mountains, reproduced on the stere
opticon
from photographs taken by members
of the
party.

UNIVERSITY CHAT.
A most remarkable display of heroism, undaunted courage and desperate defiance was
lately shown to the college by the seemingly
meek and humble freshmen. Putting their
heads together after the drawing class one afternoon, they resolved upon a desperate plan
which required courage and recklessness to
execute. We all shudder to think how these
tender lambs blindly exposed themselves to
danger. Instantly their plan decided upon,
they hurried down the precipitous stairs that
lead to the drawing-room, and with superhuman strength and courage they held the hall
door, thereby barring the exit of Dr. Whiteman. Resolutely they held, not one bit
daunted, as they heard the slow, firm tread of
Dr. Whiteman descending the stairs. He has
passed the second story and is now descending
to the first floor.
"They spake not a word;
But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,
Gazed each on other, and looked deathly pale."
—Richard III.
The Doctor tried the door, but it yielded
not, and brooding suspicion awakened in his
mind a realization that some outward force was
resisting his efforts. Immediately his stern
voice reached the ears of the freshmen without.
Their courage wavered, fell, rose and then departed forever. Scattered and in confusion
they ran, nor did they stop until they were
safely harbored in the quiet repose of McCoy

A PROTEST.
In our lagt number appeared an editorial,
treating of the disadvantages of the petition
concerning the rent on gymnasium lockers.
Of course, the question has two sides, and our
writer had strong convictions with the small
minority. He was, however, undoubtedly,
mistaken in supposing that a fee for the use of
lockers would deter students from exercising
in the gymnasium—simply because attendance
to gymnasium work is compulsory for all
undergraduates. This is an old rule, which
could not be strictly enforced in former years
for lack of space in the old building.
During the past years the single teams paid
their expenses by scanty contributions from a
part of the students. Under this system the
managers found themselves continually on the
verge of bankruptcy. To remedy this evil, the
new Athletic Association was formed, which
has under its supervision the expenses of all
the teams wearing the black and blue. The
income derived from a yearly rent on the lockers will place the Athletic Association, and
with it the whole field of Hopkins athletics, on
a secure financial basis. Never again will the
managers have to go begging through the
University. The equipment of teams, the salaries of coaches and trainers, will be assured
for the whole future. The eventual surplus of
prosperous years may secure, as the students'
property, the long hoped-for athletic field. The
failure to procure this money would leave
Hopkins athletics in their old stage of stagnation. The only reliable income would be the
money derived from the membership dues for
the Athletic Association, a paltry sum, as compared with the necessary expenses.
For years past we have clamored over our
lack of college spirit, of interest in college athletics. We have looked here and there for
causes, and for remedies. The cause lies with
us, the remedy can come from us only. Surely,
this is the time to prove our loyalty by consenting, one and all, to the lasting welfare of
our athletics. Let us pay.
For some of the poorest students enthusiasm
and expense can never form a pair. We have

little doubt that the Treasurer could find
means of lightening their burden.
